ygData.subject: Help with crossover technique.
ygData.msgSnippet: I ve looked into SharpNEAT s crossover algorithm and it is definitely doing a full combine of both parent genomes, so the new genome will get all of the

From: Colin Green <cgreen@...>
Subject: Help with crossover technique.
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=127853030
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod


I've looked into SharpNEAT's crossover algorithm and it is definitely 
doing a full combine of both parent genomes, so the new genome will get 
all of the fittest parent's genes plus any excess & disjoint from the 
other parent. If the parents are of equal fitness then matching genes 
are selected from randomly (50% chance of getting gene from either 
parent), and ALL of the excess and disjoint genes from both parents are 
included.

So now I'm trying to sort this out by going back to Ken's NEAT papers 
for an explanation on the crossover technique, but I'm having 
difficulty. From "Competitive Coevolution through Evolutionary 
Complexification", section 3.2, paragraph 4:

-----------------
"Through innovation numbers, the system now knows exactly which genes 
match up with which (Figure 4). Genes that do not match are either 
/disjoint/ or /excess/, depending on whether they occur within or 
outside the range of the other parent's innovation numbers. When 
crossing over, the genes with the same innovation numbers are lined up 
and are randomly chosen for the offspring genome. Genes that do not 
match are inherited from the more fit parent, or if they are equally 
fit, from both parents randomly. Disabled genes have a 25% chance of 
being reenabled during crossover, allowing networks to make use of older 
genes once again."
-----------------

So I'm doing a couple of things wrong:

1) When genes match I take the gene from the fittest parent. Whereas I 
should be randomly selecting from both parents. Right? Currently I only 
to this if both parent are equally fit.
2) I am always including *all* excess and disjoint genes from the least 
fit parent.


However I am not 100% sure how original NEAT works w.r.t this second 
point...

"Genes that do not match are inherited from the more fit parent, or if 
they are equally fit, from both parents randomly."

So just to be clear on this, this is saying that excess and disjoint 
genes from the least fit parent are not used, right? and if both parents 
are equal, should I take all of the excess and disjoint genes from both 
parents or just some percentage of them? I think the term 'randomly' in 
this senetence is confusing me, does it mean that I should only be 
selecting a sub-set of the excess and disjoint genes from both parents, 
or is it merely alluding to the fact that the excess and disjoint genes 
are distributed acrosss the two parents, and that therefore we are 
selecting them from whichever parent they happen to be on, but it's not 
actually a random selection as such.


Something about this doesn't seem right to me. It means that the 
crossover almost always only combines weight values, not topolgies. e.g. 
in my OCR experiment, if two different genomes have each discovered a 
distinct beneficial input-output connection then the only way we can 
combine the two genomes to get the benefit of both connections is if 
they happen to have the same fitness, right?

If this is the case then I would have thought it would be better to use 
excess and disjoint genes from the least fit parent more often, like 
when the parent are unequal.

Colin.
